entry.name: ‎Antigenic drift‎
entry.description: mechanism for variation in viruses

entry.name: ‎antiviral drug‎
entry.description: Class of medications

entry.name: ‎bacteriophage‎
entry.description: virus that infects and replicates within bacteria

entry.name: ‎capsid‎
entry.description: protein coat that surrounds the infective nucleic acid in some virus particles. It comprises numerous regularly arranged subunits, or capsomeres.

entry.name: ‎giant virus‎
entry.description: giant nucleocytoplasmic large DNA viruses that have extremely large genomes compared to other viruses and contain many unique genes not found in other life forms

entry.name: ‎A roadmap to the human virome‎
entry.description: scientific article

entry.name: ‎microbiology‎
entry.description: study of microscopic organisms

entry.name: ‎neurotropic virus‎
entry.description: virus that is capable of infecting nerve cells

entry.name: ‎oncovirus‎
entry.description: viruses that can cause cancer

entry.name: ‎Reassortment‎
entry.description: mixing of the genetic material

entry.name: ‎viral infectious disease‎
entry.description: Human, animal or plant disease resulting from a viral infection

entry.name: ‎Viral entry‎
entry.description: The process that occurs after viral attachment by which a virus, or viral nucleic acid, breaches the plasma membrane or cell envelope and enters the host cell. The process ends when the viral nucleic acid is released into the host cell cytoplasm.

entry.name: ‎viral envelope‎
entry.description: lipid bilayer of a virion that surrounds the protein capsid, and may also contain glycoproteins

entry.name: ‎positive regulation of viral life cycle‎
entry.description: Any process that activates or increases the frequency, rate or extent of viral life cycle.

entry.name: ‎viral protein‎
entry.description: proteins found in any species of virus

entry.name: ‎viral replication‎
entry.description: formation of biological viruses during the infection process in the target host cells

entry.name: ‎viral shedding‎
entry.description: The dissemination of mature viral particles from the host cell, e.g. by cell lysis or the budding of virus particles from the cell membrane.

entry.name: ‎Viroplasm‎
entry.description: cellular compartment in which viruses replicate

entry.name: ‎virus-like particle‎
entry.description: virion that lacks nucleic acid

entry.name: ‎virus classification‎
entry.description: organisation of viruses into a taxonomic system

entry.name: ‎Virus latency‎
entry.description: Ability of some viruses to lie dormant within a cell

entry.name: ‎virus quantification‎
entry.description: microbiological method regarding viruses
